title: How much can you trust a reference of a paper that is not available? - Quora

response.answer_text: Back in the 7th or 8th grade, we had to write one page book reports, maybe just on index cards. A bunch of slacker boys decided to make up the books, instead of actually reading them, and settled on the name “Sidney Charles” as the author. They figured that if they used the same author, then the teacher would believe them. I don’t think they ever got caught. So if somebody cites a paper by “Sidney Charles” and it is not available? It would seem pretty sketchy to me. “Hey, wait a minute, weren’t you a slacker at the Atkinson School?” Or more seriously, the person looking for the paper may not have the strongest digital research skills, and might want to ask the university librarian for some assistance. Unless of course, this is archival material, and in that case, it would be cited differently than a scholarly paper.

It depends how central the missing reference is to the argument put forth in the paper. For example, if the missing reference supposedly rules out or eliminates one of the alternate explanations or theoretical positions, then it’s absence is very important.
